element.name: Ein Stein by toczygroszek (adopted by anacreon), Traditional Cache (1/1)

long-description.p:
Prior to the 17th century, the north side of Townsend was a tidal strand of the Liffey. To the south there was an elevated ridge near the confluence of the rivers Liffey and Dodder and that was the place where Dublin Vikings generally landed. Old records refer to this place as “The Stein” or “Steine”.
The name “Steine” has got Scandinavian roots and comes from “stone”. Some records mention a pillar stone standing there. Destruction or moving this stone is not recorded, and its function is not clear. Most likely it was a cult stone (dedicated to Freya or Thor) but other theories mention a memory stone, a mark of possession or a seamark (for navigation).
In the 1970's a replica was erected near the original location.
The cache:
Cache is a magnetic micro container and includes logbook and pencil.
Please retrieve and hide the cache with extreme care because it’s a highly muggled area.

ul.li:
2010-06-14T19:00:00Z : Found it by scheff
Together with sina1507 we started our holiday in Dublin today with geocaching. TFTC scheff from Germany

Easy find on route to work this morning. SL TFTC

2010-06-11T19:00:00Z : Found it by Mie G
Visit from Denmark

2010-06-08T19:00:00Z : Didn't find it by Die-3-Fragezeichen
Couldn't find in detail due to too many muggles. But should have been enough for a D1 T1 one. :-(

2010-04-03T19:00:00Z : Write note by Kersti.com
The tenth cache today with EdwardsClan - but I've found it before so just a note that it's here :)

2009-03-27T19:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
Spotted this one when I was checking emails because I couldn't sleep. It was on my way to work so I managed to stop by and do a quick grab. Happy to see that I snagged the FTF :) Some tourist-like behaviour was necessary as there were so many muggles around, but they were mostly concentrating on getting to work. TFTC

wpt.name: GC1NTJM

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Ein Stein
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Prior to the 17th century, the north side of Townsend was a tidal strand of the Liffey. To the south there was an elevated ridge near the confluence of the rivers Liffey and Dodder and that was the place where Dublin Vikings generally landed. Old records refer to this place as “The Stein” or “Steine”.

The name “Steine” has got Scandinavian roots and comes from “stone”. Some records mention a pillar stone standing there. Destruction or moving this stone is not recorded, and its function is not clear. Most likely it was a cult stone (dedicated to Freya or Thor) but other theories mention a memory stone, a mark of possession or a seamark (for navigation).

In the 1970's a replica was erected near the original location.

The cache:

Cache is a magnetic micro container and includes logbook and pencil.

Please retrieve and hide the cache with extreme care because it’s a highly muggled area.
